column1: ~ 12:00|"about noon"|"But we had to change our purpose about San Miguel
column2: for a storm came up about noon that so tossed and pitched the vessel that common sense dictated a run for shelter. Therefore we steered for the nearest island of the group—Fayal (the people there pronounce it Fy-all
column3: and put the accent on the first syllable). We anchored in the open roadstead of Horta
column4: half a mile from the shore. The town has eight thousand to ten thousand inhabitants. Its snow-white houses nestle cosily in a sea of fresh green vegetation
column5: and no village could look prettier or more attractive. It sits in the lap of an amphitheater of hills which are three hundred to seven hundred feet high
column6: and carefully cultivated clear to their summits—not a foot of soil left idle. Every farm and every acre is cut up into little square inclosures by stone walls
column7: whose duty it is to protect the growing products from the destructive gales that blow there. These hundreds of green squares
column8: marked by their black lava walls
column9: make the hills look like vast checkerboards."|"The Innocents Abroad"|"Mark Twain"

column1: 07:00|"seven o'clock this lovely morning"|"Everybody was sent scampering to the deck at seven o'clock this lovely morning of the thirtieth of June with the glad news that land was in sight! It was a rare thing and a joyful
column2: to see all the ship's family abroad once more
column3: albeit the happiness that sat upon every countenance could only partly conceal the ravages which that long siege of storms had wrought there. But dull eyes soon sparkled with pleasure
column4: pallid cheeks flushed again
column5: and frames weakened by sickness gathered new life from the quickening influences of the bright
column6: fresh morning. Yea
column7: and from a still more potent influence: the worn castaways were to see the blessed land again!—and to see it was to bring back that motherland that was in all their thoughts."|"The Innocents Abroad"|"Mark Twain"

column1: ap 11:00|"eleven o'clock"|"At eleven o'clock we alighted upon a sign which manifestly referred to billiards. Joy! We had played billiards in the Azores with balls that were not round and on an ancient table that was very little smoother than a brick pavement—one of those wretched old things with dead cushions
column2: and with patches in the faded cloth and invisible obstructions that made the balls describe the most astonishing and unsuspected angles and perform feats in the way of unlooked-for and almost impossible ""scratches"" that were perfectly bewildering. We had played at Gibraltar with balls the size of a walnut
column3: on a table like a public square—and in both instances we achieved far more aggravation than amusement. We expected to fare better here
column4: but we were mistaken. The cushions were a good deal higher than the balls
column5: and as the balls had a fashion of always stopping under the cushions
column6: we accomplished very little in the way of caroms. The cushions were hard and unelastic
column7: and the cues were so crooked that in making a shot you had to allow for the curve or you would infallibly put the ""English"" on the wrong side of the hall. Dan was to mark while the doctor and I played. At the end of an hour neither of us had made a count
column8: and so Dan was tired of keeping tally with nothing to tally
column9: and we were heated and angry and disgusted. We paid the heavy bill—about six cents—and said we would call around sometime when we had a week to spend
column10: and finish the game."|"The Innocents Abroad"|"Mark Twain"

column3: and so we drowsed on through the chill night air and dreamed of camp fires
column4: warm beds
column5: and other comfortable things."|"The Innocents Abroad"|"Mark Twain"

column1: ap 04:00|"four o'clock"|"We reached the famous river before four o'clock
column2: and the night was so black that we could have ridden into it without seeing it. Some of us were in an unhappy frame of mind. We waited and waited for daylight
column3: but it did not come. Finally we went away in the dark and slept an hour on the ground
column4: in the bushes
column5: and caught cold. It was a costly nap
column6: on that account
column7: but otherwise it was a paying investment because it brought unconsciousness of the dreary minutes and put us in a somewhat fitter mood for a first glimpse of the sacred river."|"The Innocents Abroad"|"Mark Twain"

column1: 10:00|"ten in the morning"|"At nine or ten in the morning we reached the Plain of the Shepherds
column2: and stood in a walled garden of olives where the shepherds were watching their flocks by night
column3: eighteen centuries ago
column4: when the multitude of angels brought them the tidings that the Saviour was born. A quarter of a mile away was Bethlehem of Judea
column5: and the pilgrims took some of the stone wall and hurried on."|"The Innocents Abroad"|"Mark Twain"

column1: ap ~ 03:00|"about three o'clock"|"We visited all the holy places about Jerusalem which we had left unvisited when we journeyed to the Jordan and then
column2: about three o'clock one afternoon
column3: we fell into procession and marched out at the stately Damascus gate
column4: and the walls of Jerusalem shut us out forever. We paused on the summit of a distant hill and took a final look and made a final farewell to the venerable city which had been such a good home to us."|"The Innocents Abroad"|"Mark Twain"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"""Sunday—Morning service
column2: four bells. Evening service
column3: eight bells. Monotony till midnight.—Whereupon
column4: dominoes."|"The Innocents Abroad"|"Mark Twain"

column1: 00:00|midnight|"""No date—Anchored off the picturesque city of Cagliari
column2: Sardinia. Staid till midnight
column3: but not permitted to land by these infamous foreigners. They smell inodorously—they do not wash—they dare not risk cholera."|"The Innocents Abroad"|"Mark Twain"

column1: ap 11:00|"eleven o'clock"|"Ten or eleven o'clock found us coming down to breakfast one morning in Cadiz. They told us the ship had been lying at anchor in the harbor two or three hours. It was time for us to bestir ourselves. The ship could wait only a little while because of the quarantine. We were soon on board
column2: and within the hour the white city and the pleasant shores of Spain sank down behind the waves and passed out of sight. We had seen no land fade from view so regretfully."|"The Innocents Abroad"|"Mark Twain"
